awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: Pulse Radiolysis Studies of H2 Generation by [Cp*Rh] Complexes to Characterize Design Rules for Improved Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description

Renewable energy sources, which provide power without routine emission of pollutants, are being developed rapidly in the United States and elsewhere. However, effective and practical methods for the direct generation of useful chemicals using renewable energy remain elusive. In part, this challenge arises from a lack of detailed and predictive information on the individual steps involved in energy-storing chemical reactions such as hydrogen generation or carbon dioxide conversion. With the support of an EPSCoR Research Fellowship, the PI will conduct research at Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL), where he and his collaborators will focus on revealing the detailed features of selected energy-storing reactions as they proceed step-by-step. Unique resources available at BNL, including techniques that can monitor reactions in real time as they occur, will be used to conduct studies of active materials developed in the PI?s laboratory at the University of Kansas. Within the framework of this research, the PI and his students will closely collaborate with scientists in the BNL Artificial Photosynthesis group, fostering a strong partnership between institutions that will enable mutually beneficial exchange of knowledge and expertise while also accelerating research progress. More broadly, this effort will further scientific workforce development in Kansas by providing opportunities for enhanced training and dissemination of research findings in local and regional forums.  

Technical Description

The research effort of this fellowship focuses on experimental study of mechanisms of proton and electron management in reductive molecular catalysis. Proton/electron management is important in artificial photosynthetic systems that can be used to generate energy-dense chemicals and fuels; in such systems, water serves as a sacrificial reagent to provide reducing equivalents to catalysts that mediate formation of reduced products. A group of [Cp*Rh]-based molecular catalysts (Cp* = pentamethylcyclopentadienyl; Rh = rhodium) developed in the PI?s laboratory are the target of the studies in this project, as they are highly active for catalysis, recyclable, and built from commonly available components. However, unexpected metal- and ligand-centered protonation events have recently been implicated in the activity of these compounds, motivating detailed studies aimed at revealing the features of their structure and bonding that favor efficient catalysis. On-site experimental work at BNL will focus on pulse radiolysis and time-resolved UV-visible and infrared spectroscopic studies in order to generate and observe the transient intermediates involved in catalysis, with the goal of elucidating the roles of specific protonation sites, metal hydride species, and ancillary redox-active ligands. Complexes that feature a variety of ligand environments will be studied, including model compounds that complement the active catalysts. The outcomes of this research include fundamental knowledge for rational design of improved molecular catalysts, particularly systems with ligand environments built upon cyclopentadienyl-type ligands that may function as unconventional proton relays. Notably, the design rules developed here could be broadly useful, as cyclopentadienyl ligands are ubiquitous in organometallic chemistry and catalysis, and are commonly used in industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: University of Kansas Center for Research Inc
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF KANSAS CENTER FOR RESEARCH INC

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on understanding the catalytic mechanisms that can give rise to effective hydrogen (H2) production. Hydrogen is a sustainable fuel that can be used to store renewable energy; it is composed of four simple particles, two protons (2H+) and two electrons (2e-). Catalytic proton reduction can be used to generate H2, but the elementary reaction steps that occur during catalysis are challenging to observe and understand, limiting rational development of improved systems. In this project, structural and spectroscopic data regarding the individual catalytic intermediates leading to H2 production were sought, in order to map the reactivity of catalysts with H+ and e-. Changes in catalyst structure and bonding during such multistep reactions can affect the nature of the intermediate forms of the catalyst, thereby governing catalytic activity and efficiency. Consequently, in this project the PI partnered with scientists in the Artificial Photosynthesis Group at Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL) as an NSF EPSCoR Research Fellow to carry out studies of catalytic intermediates and mechanism in the context of H2 production.

In particular, the goal of the research was to reveal the structural and electronic features of the [Cp*Rh] catalyst platform (where Cp* is pentamethylcyclopentadienyl and Rh is rhodium) that give rise to high activity for H2 generation. This system was selected for study because it is stable over a wide pH range, is recyclable, shows excellent catalytic yields of H2, and is built from commonly available components. However, the system has been shown to undergo both metal-centered hydride formation as well as protonation of the Cp* ligand ring, and thus little mechanistic detail was available on the structural features that favor fast and efficient H2 generation. Cp*-centered reactivity is quite unusual, but understanding the origin of this behavior could have implications across a number of important catalytic systems, because the Cp* ligand is a common supporting ligand in inorganic and organometallic chemistry.

Through this project, pulse radiolysis (PR) and stopped-flow (SF) techniques were used to generate and observe catalytic intermediates on very fast timescales (down to picoseconds) and with structural specificity by UV-visible and infrared absorption spectroscopy. PR was used to study reduction of the catalyst, while stopped-flow UV-visible spectroscopy with rapid mixing was used to measure the kinetics of individual proton transfer steps as well as H-H evolution. Based on the results, initial proton transfer to the reduced form of the catalyst, Cp*Rh(bpy) (where bpy is 2,2'-bipyridyl), was shown to result in generation of a transient [Cp*Rh] hydride; this monohydride has been often invoked as a possible intermediate in the literature, but was rigorously identified and characterized here for the first time. Following generation of this hydride, the catalyst was shown to undergo tautomerization that results in generation of the species bearing protonated Cp*. Temperature-dependent studies and H/D isotope effect measurements were carried out for both of these reactions, providing information on the activation parameters and kinetic barriers involved. This high level of detail represents a foundation of knowledge that could be used to design new catalysts that could take advantage of the ligand-centered protonation of Cp*. Additionally, the results represent a comprehensive mechanistic study that reveals the full set of elementary steps involved in H2 generation by the Cp*Rh(bpy) platform, and the dependence of those steps on the strength of acid used to drive catalysis.

This project took place in the context of the fields of organometallic chemistry and energy science. Both of these are growing areas of interest, due to the high importance of metal-based catalysts and renewable energy sources in sustainability and mitigation of risks associated with anthropogenic climate change. On the organometallic side, the project provided a valuable new perspective on the chemistry of Cp*, one of the most common and useful ligands available. The project also generated significant enthusiasm and excitement, a situation attributable to the simplicity of the parent catalyst structure, the ubiquity of the ligands involved, and the uniqueness of the reactivity patterns uncovered in the chemistry of the system.

In summary, this project elucidated the mechanistic basis of H2 evolution with [Cp*Rh]-based catalysts, and expanded the synthetic chemistry of key protonated forms of [Cp*Rh] compounds. Hydrides and protonated Cp* species were both found to be involved in catalytic H2 evolution, and the selection of supporting ligands was found to influence the involvement of these species in the chemistry of the system. In parallel with the mechanistic studies, synthetic efforts were carried out to develop new ligand environments and isolate key model compounds, including hydrides, providing a library of structures for exploration and new applications. Taken together, the results demonstrate the power of mechanistic studies with pulse radiolysis and stopped-flow spectroscopic techniques, and the power of synthetic chemistry. The future appears bright for utilization of these techniques in studies of redox chemistry and catalysis.


Last Modified: 11/04/2021
Modified by: James D Blakemore
